paper_title: FOTBCD: A Large-Scale Building Change Detection Benchmark from French Orthophotos and Topographic Data

sections.title: Abstract
sections.content: We introduce FOTBCD, a large-scale building change detection dataset derived from authoritative French orthophotos and topographic building data provided by IGN France. Unlike existing benchmarks that are geographically constrained to single cities or limited regions, FOTBCD spans 28 departments across mainland France, with 25 used for training and three geographically disjoint departments held out for evaluation. The dataset covers diverse urban, suburban, and rural environments at 0.2m/pixel resolution. We publicly release FOTBCD-Binary, a dataset comprising approximately 28,000 before/after image pairs with pixel-wise binary building change masks, each associated with patch-level spatial metadata. The dataset is designed for large-scale benchmarking and evaluation under geographic domain shift, with validation and test samples drawn from held-out departments and manually verified to ensure label quality. In addition, we publicly release FOTBCD-Instances, a publicly available instance-level annotated subset comprising several thousand image pairs, which illustrates the complete annotation schema used in the full instance-level version of FOTBCD. Using a fixed reference baseline, we benchmark FOTBCD-Binary against LEVIR-CD+ and WHU-CD, providing strong empirical evidence that geographic diversity at the dataset level is associated with improved cross-domain generalization in building change detection.

sections.title: Abstract
sections.content: We introduce FOTBCD, large-scale building change detection dataset derived from authoritative French orthophotos and topographic building data provided by IGN France. Unlike existing benchmarks that are geographically constrained to single cities or limited regions, FOTBCD spans 28 departments across mainland France, with 25 used for training and three geographically disjoint departments held out for evaluation. The dataset covers diverse urban, suburban, and rural environments at 0.2 m/pixel resolution. We publicly release FOTBCD-Binary, dataset comprising approximately 28,000 before/after image pairs with pixel-wise binary building change masks, each associated with patch-level spatial metadata. The dataset is designed for large-scale benchmarking and evaluation under geographic domain shift, with validation and test samples drawn from held-out departments and manually verified to ensure label quality. In addition, we publicly release FOTBCD-Instances, publicly available instance-level annotated subset comprising several thousand image pairs, which illustrates the complete annotation schema used in the full instance-level version of FOTBCD. Using fixed reference baseline, we benchmark FOTBCD-Binary against LEVIR-CD+ and WHU-CD, providing strong empirical evidence that geographic diversity at the dataset level is associated with improved cross-domain generalization in building change detection.

sections.title: 1 Introduction
sections.content: Building change detection from remote sensing imagery is essential for urban planning, cadastral updates, disaster response, and environmental monitoring. Deep learning has driven significant progress, but model development and evaluation remain constrained by the limitations of existing datasets. Current change detection benchmarks suffer from two critical limitations: Geographic Homogeneity. LEVIR-CD+ [1] covers 20 regions in Texas, USA, while WHU-CD [4] consists of single image pair from Christchurch, New Zealand. Models trained on such geographically constrained data learn region-specific featuresparticular building styles, urban layouts, vegetation patterns, and imaging conditions that fail to generalize across geographic domains. Limited Scale and Diversity. Existing datasets contain hundreds to thousands of image pairs, insufficient to capture the full variability of real-world change detection scenarios, including dense urban cores, suburban sprawl, rural villages, industrial zones, and varying terrain. We address these limitations with FOTBCD, dataset family derived from Frances authoritative geographic databases. In this work, we focus on the public release of FOTBCD-Binary, large-scale benchmark for binary building change detection: National Coverage: 28 departments across mainland France (25 for training and 3 held out for evaluation), spanning diverse geographic and urban contexts from Mediterranean coastal regions to rural Atlantic areas. High Resolution: 0.2 m/pixel aerial orthophotos from IGNs BD ORTHO database. Binary Change Annotations: CHANGE / NO-CHANGE masks large-scale benchmarking. Pixel-wise suitable for Spatially Referenced: All patches are associated with patch-level spatial metadata, including projected-coordinate bounding boxes, enabling GIS integration. Scale: Approximately 28,000 image pairs yielding over 100,000 training 256x256 patches. In addition, we release FOTBCD-Instances (Research Dataset), smaller subset with instancelevel polygon annotations distinguishing NEW, DEMOLISHED, and UNCHANGED buildings, illustrating the full annotation schema and enabling instance-level experimentation. Our experiments demonstrate that geographic diversity is key factor for cross-domain generalization. Models trained on geographically limited datasets (LEVIR-CD+ and WHU-CD) exhibit substantial performance degradation when evaluated on FOTBCD-Binary. In contrast, model trained on FOTBCD-Binary transfers effectively to WHU-CD and comparably to LEVIR-CD+ in relative terms, despite differences in imagery source and regional characteristics.

sections.title: 2.1 Change Detection Datasets
sections.content: Table 1 summarizes widely used building change detection datasets. LEVIR-CD [1] contains 637 pairs of 10241024 Google Earth images at 0.5 resolution, covering approximately 20 regions in Texas, USA. Changes are annotated as binary masks focusing on building construction. The dataset is widely used but geographically homogeneous. WHU-CD [4] provides single large pair of aerial images (32,50715,354 pixels at 0.2 resolution) from Christchurch, New Zealand, captured before and after the 2011 earthquake. While high-resolution, it represents only one city and single change event. LEVIR-CD+ extends LEVIR-CD with additional image pairs while maintaining the same geographic scope and annotation format. In contrast, FOTBCD-Binary provides large-scale geographic diversity at the national level, enabling evaluation across wide range of urban, suburban, and rural environments. In addition, we release FOTBCDInstances, smaller subset with instance-level polygon annotations distinguishing NEW, DEMOLISHED, and UNCHANGED buildings, illustrating the full annotation schema.

sections.title: Sensing
sections.content: Domain shift between training and deployment regions is well-known challenge in remote sensing [6]. Variations in building architecture, urban density, land cover, terrain, and imaging conditions often cause models to underperform when applied to geographically distinct areas. Prior work has primarily addressed this problem through domain adaptation and normalization techniques. In contrast, we argue that increasing geographic diversity at the dataset level is more fundamental and scalable approach to improving cross-region generalization.

sections.title: 3.2 Geographic Coverage
sections.content: FOTBCD-Binary spans 28 departments across mainland France, with 25 departments used for training and 3 geographically disjoint departments held out for validation and testing (Figure 1). The split is performed at the department level to ensure zero geographic overlap between training and evaluation data, enabling an unbiased assessment of cross-region generalization. The selected departments were chosen to maximize geographic, environmental, and urban diversity. Together, they cover wide range of French landscapes, including: Dense urban and peri-urban regions, encompassing large metropolitan areas and their surroundings Coastal departments along both the Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea Rural and agricultural areas, including plains and low-density regions Mountainous and foothill regions, covering parts of the Alps and the Pyrenees Industrial and mixed-use regions in northern and eastern France This geographic diversity results in substantial variability in: FOTBCD is derived from two authoritative geospatial databases maintained by the Institut National de lInformation Geographique et Foresti`ere (IGN), Frances national mapping agency. BD ORTHO [2] provides seamless aerial orthophoto coverage of mainland France at ground sampling distance of 0.2 m. The dataset consists of RGB imagery acquired through regular national aerial survey campaigns, with update cycles ranging from 34 years depending on the region. The imagery is radiometrically corrected and orthorectified to ensure geometric consistency across large areas. sections.title: 3.3 Annotation Schema
sections.content: FOTBCD is released in two complementary variants with distinct annotation granularities. FOTBCD-Binary, the primary public benchmark used for all experiments in this work, provides pixelwise binary change annotations indicating the presence or absence of building change between two temporal images. These binary masks are derived from building-level change inference and are designed for large-scale benchmarking and cross-domain generalization studies. In addition, we release FOTBCD-Instances, smaller subset with instance-level polygon annotations in COCO format. This subset illustrates the full annotation schema and supports instance-level analysis and experimentation. Each building instance is assigned one of three semantic classes: 1. UNCHANGED (category id=1): present in both temporal images. Buildings 2. DEMOLISHED (category id=2): Buildings present in the before image but absent in the after image. 3. NEW (category id=3): Buildings absent in the before image but present in the after image. For binary change detection, the NEW and DEMOLISHED classes are merged into single CHANGE category, while UNCHANGED buildings are ignored. The instance-level polygon representation enables precise boundary evaluation beyond pixel-wise metrics, instance-level performance analysis, and future research on multi-class and instance-aware change detection. sections.title: 3.4 Data Splits and Quality Control
sections.content: FOTBCD-Binary employs strict geographic split strategy to ensure unbiased evaluation under cross-region domain shift. Training Set. Training data are derived automatically from temporal differences in BD TOPO, aligned with corresponding BD ORTHO imagery. Building-level change signals are inferred using combination of rule-based filtering, domain-specific heuristics, and learned components, and subsequently converted into binary change masks. As with most large-scale automatically generated datasets, the training set may contain limited label noise. However, our experimental results indicate that this noise does not materially affect model performance. Validation and Test Sets. Validation and test data are sourced from three departments that are completely excluded from the training set, ensuring zero geographic overlap. All validation and test samples are manually selected and verified by human annotators, providing reliable evaluation benchmark despite potential noise in the training data. The quality control pipeline includes: 1. Temporal Alignment: Ensuring consistency between BD ORTHO acquisition dates and BD TOPO snapshot dates. 2. Topological and Semantic Validation: Detailed analysis of BD TOPO building geometry and metadata, followed by the application of domain-specific rules to remove implausible or inconsistent changes. 3. AI-Based Filtering: Automated detection of residual inconsistencies and rare edge cases. 4. Human Verification: Manual inspection of all validation and test samples to eliminate remaining label errors.

sections.title: 3.5 Qualitative Examples
sections.content: Figure 2 presents grid of qualitative visualizations from FOTBCD. The figure is arranged as grid with two before/after image pairs per row. For each pair, building polygons are drawn to illustrate the visual interpretation of building changes between the two temporal images. Polygon overlays follow visualization-specific convention: DEMOLISHED buildings are drawn only on the before image, NEW buildings are drawn only on the after image, and UNCHANGED buildings are drawn on both images. This convention is used solely for visual clarity and does not reflect the underlying annotation storage format.

sections.title: 4 HybridSiam-CD: Reference Baseline
sections.content: To benchmark FOTBCD-Binary, we use HybridSiamCD, reference change detection model that combines pretrained Vision Transformer features with CNN-based boundary refinement. The model is not proposed as new architecture, but is used solely to provide consistent and reasonably strong baseline for cross-dataset evaluation.

sections.title: 4.1 Architecture
sections.content: HybridSiam-CD follows siamese design with separate semantic and spatial processing branches: Semantic Encoder: frozen DINOv3-sat493M [5] Vision Transformer pretrained on satellite imagery extracts high-level semantic features from both temporal images. Absolute feature differences are used to encode change information. Spatial Branch: siamese ResNet34 pretrained on ImageNet provides multi-scale spatial and boundary cues. Fusion Decoder: lightweight decoder fuses semantic and spatial features using skip connections and upsampling to produce dense change maps. The Vision Transformer encoder is kept frozen during training, resulting in limited number of trainable parameters. This design prioritizes stability and reproducibility over architectural optimization.

sections.title: 5.1 Cross-Domain Generalization
sections.content: The primary experiment evaluates cross-dataset generalization under geographic domain shift. Table 4 reports Intersection-over-Union (IoU) scores when training on one dataset and evaluating on another. Key observations: Generalization to FOTBCD-Binary. Models trained on geographically constrained datasets exhibit substantial performance degradation when evaluated on 5 FOTBCD-Binary. LEVIR-CD+ and WHU-CD achieve IoU scores of 0.3003 and 0.3417, respectively, indicating limited transfer to more geographically diverse, national-scale dataset. Generalization from FOTBCD-Binary. model trained on FOTBCD-Binary generalizes well to WHUCD, achieving an IoU of 0.6974, and performs comparably to the inverse transfer when evaluated on LEVIR-CD+ (0.2984). While cross-dataset performance remains below in-domain results, these outcomes are consistently more balanced than those observed when transferring from geographically constrained datasets to FOTBCD-Binary. Asymmetric domain shift. Cross-evaluation between LEVIR-CD+ and WHU-CD also results in large performance drops relative to in-domain training, confirming that geographic domain shift is general challenge in building change detection and not specific to any single dataset. In particular, models trained constrained benchmarks. on FOTBCD-Binary generalize more consistently across datasets, while models trained on LEVIR-CD+ or WHUCD experience substantial performance degradation when evaluated on FOTBCD-Binary. FOTBCD is intended as foundation for future research on geographically robust change detection. By releasing both large-scale binary benchmark and smaller instance-level dataset, we aim to support broad range of research directions, from semantic change detection to instance-level analysis.

sections.title: Data Availability and Licensing
sections.content: FOTBCD is released under clear separation between publicly available research datasets and larger, nonpublic dataset intended for commercial use. FOTBCD-Binary (Research Dataset). The primary dataset used for training and evaluation in this paper is publicly released for research use under the CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 license (https://creativecommons. org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/deed.en). It includes: approximately 28,000 before/after image pairs, pixel-wise binary building change masks derived from authoritative vector data, human-verified validation and test splits. FOTBCD-Instances (Research Subset). publicly available instance-level research subset, released under the same CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 license, comprising approximately 4,000 before/after image pairs with dedicated validation and test splits. The dataset is annotated with building polygons labeled as NEW, DEMOLISHED, or UNCHANGED, and supports instance-level training and evaluation as complement to the binary benchmark. Repository Access. Both public research datasets (FOTBCD-Binary and FOTBCD-Instances) are distributed through single public GitHub repository together with training code, configuration files, and pretrained model checkpoints: https://github.com/ abdelpy/FOTBCD-datasets. FOTBCD-220k (Internal Research Data). In addition to the public research datasets, larger instance-level dataset comprising over 220,000 image pairs has been constructed for internal research and commercial applications. This dataset is not publicly released and is distributed separately under commercial license. Access may be granted to academic institutions within the context of collaborative research projects.

sections.title: 6.1 Why Geographic Diversity Matters
sections.content: Our experiments indicate that geographic diversity at the dataset level is key factor for improving robustness to cross-region domain shift in building change detection. This observation is consistent with findings in other machine learning domains, where diversity in training data often has greater impact on out-of-distribution performance than raw dataset size. The 25 training departments included in FOTBCDBinary span wide range of geographic and environmental conditions, including: Multiple climate regimes (oceanic, continental, Mediterranean, mountain, and semi-arid) Diverse architectural styles and settlement patterns Terrain variations ranging from lowland plains to mountainous regions Exposure to this diversity encourages models to learn more general change-related cues, rather than overfitting to region-specific building appearances, layouts, or imaging conditions. This effect is reflected in the crossdataset evaluation results, where models trained on geographically constrained benchmarks struggle to generalize to FOTBCD-Binary, while training on more diverse national-scale dataset leads to more balanced transfer behavior.

sections.title: 6.2 Limitations
sections.content: Despite its scale and geographic diversity, FOTBCD has limitations: National scope: The dataset is limited to mainland France. While it spans diverse regions and environments, evaluation across multiple countries or continents would require additional datasets. Building-centric annotations: The annotations focus exclusively on building changes; other change categories such as roads, vegetation, or land use are not labeled.

sections.title: 7 Conclusion
sections.content: We introduced FOTBCD, national-scale building change detection dataset derived from Frances authoritative geographic data, designed to support robust evaluation under geographic domain shift. The dataset spans 25 training departments with three geographically disjoint departments reserved for validation and testing, covering wide range of urban, suburban, and rural environments at 0.2 spatial resolution.
